Wool is the textile fiber obtained from sheep and certain other animals, including cashmere and mohair from goats, qiviut from muskoxen, hide and fur clothing from bison, angora from rabbits, and other types of wool from camelids.

Wool is the textile fiber obtained from sheep and other animals, including cashmere and mohair from goats, qiviut from muskoxen, angora from rabbits, and other types of wool from camelids; additionally, the Highland and the Mangalica breeds of cattle and swine, respectively, possess wooly coats.
Sheep's milk is the milk of domestic sheep. It is commonly used to make cultured dairy products such as cheese.

The meat of sheep is called lamb.

Sheepskin is the hide of a sheep, sometimes also called lambskin. Unlike common leather, sheepskin is tanned with the fleece intact, as in a pelt. Sheepskin numnahs, saddle pads, saddle seat savers, sheepskin horse boots, tack linings and girth tubes are also made and used in equestrianism.
